Present Illness.Onset: 2 weeks prior at home, gradual onset, no prodromal symptoms. Possible cause: stress at work.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Burning upper abdominal pain, intermittently severe, lasting for several hours, worsened by eating spicy food, ameliorated by antacid use. Progression with increasing frequency of pain episodes.
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Frequent acid reflux and heartburn, especially at night. Symptom onset is closely related to meals.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Patient used over-the-counter antacids with temporary relief. No prior endoscopic examination.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Patient reports feeling anxious, has had trouble sleeping due to pain and discomfort, normal appetite initially but now decreased due to fear of pain, bowel movements regular, no significant weight change.

Past History.Disease History: History of hypertension, well-controlled with medication.
Past History.Immunization History: Up-to-date with immunizations according to age.

Personal History.Living Habits: Non-smoker, drinks alcohol socially, Moderate exercise routine.
Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: Works as a software engineer, sedentary lifestyle with occasional long hours.
Personal History.Exposure History: No exposure to industrial toxins, dust, or radioactive substances.

Marital and Family History.Family History: Father had peptic ulcer disease, mother with hypertension. No family history of gastric cancer or other serious illnesses.

Systematic Examination.Chest: Clear to auscultation, heart sounds normal
Systematic Examination.Abdomen: Epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding, liver and spleen not enlarged
Systematic Examination.Limbs: Full range of motion, no edema

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Pre-admission blood tests normal. Endoscopy ordered.
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Based on patient's history of epigastric pain relieved by antacids, physical exam showing epigastric tenderness, no systemic symptoms suggesting malignancy.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Gastric cancer (no weight loss, no palpable masses), Chronic gastritis (less likely given severity of symptoms), Gastric neurosis (symptoms more likely organic), Cholecystitis/cholelithiasis (RUQ pain absent), Gastrinoma (unlikely, stable gastrin levels).

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient admitted with severe epigastric pain, history suggests peptic ulcer. Plan: Initiate PPI therapy, lifestyle modifications, endoscopy scheduled.

Daily Course Records.Record: Patient reports mild improvement with PPI, awaiting endoscopy.
Endoscopy performed, revealed a single peptic ulcer, biopsy taken. Awaiting pathology results.

Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Reviewed case on 14th November, agreed with current management, emphasized need for biopsy results for ruling out malignancy.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Shift handover on 13th November, patient stable, ongoing PPI therapy.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Patient diagnosed with peptic ulcer following endoscopy. Initial treatment with PPI and dietary advice. Awaiting biopsy results.
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: Gastroenterology consult on 13th November, recommended endoscopy.

Long-term Orders: Diet modifications: Avoid spicy food, alcohol, coffee

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: Endoscopy report: Single peptic ulcer located in the antrum, approximately 1cm, clean base. Biopsy taken.

Digestive System Diseases.Name: Peptic Ulcer
Digestive System Diseases.Symptoms: Upper abdominal pain, acid reflux, heartburn, etc.
Digestive System Diseases.Differential Diagnosis: Gastric cancer, chronic gastritis, gastric neurosis, cholecystitis, cholelithiasis, gastrinoma.
